inlineContent.text: The effect’s identifier.
The time interval on which to publish events. For example, a value of
publishes an event approximately every half-second.
The allowed timing variance when emitting events. Defaults to
, which
allows any variance.
The scheduler on which the timer runs.
Scheduler options passed to the timer. Defaults to
While it is possible to use Foundation’s
API
to create a timer in the Composable Architecture, it is not advisable. This API only allows
creating a timer on a run loop, which means when writing tests you will need to explicitly
wait for time to pass in order to see how the effect evolves in your feature.
In the Composable Architecture we test time-based effects like this by using the
, which allows us to explicitly and immediately advance time forward so that
we can see how effects emit. However, because
takes a concrete
as
its scheduler, we can’t substitute in a
during tests`.
That is why we provide
. It allows you to create a timer that works with any
scheduler, not just a run loop, which means you can use a
or
when
running your live app, but use a
in tests.
To start and stop a timer in your feature you can create the timer effect from an action
and then use the
effect to stop the timer:

code: enum Action { case startButtonTapped, stopButtonTapped, timerTicked }
func reduce(into state: inout State, action: Action) -> EffectTask<Action> {
return EffectTask.timer(id: TimerID(), every: 1, on: self.mainQueue)

inlineContent.text: Then to test the timer in this feature you can use a test scheduler to advance time:
This effect is only meant to be used with features built in the Composable
Architecture, and returned from a reducer. If you want a testable alternative to
Foundation’s
you can use the publisher
that is included
in this library via the
module.
Use 'clock.timer' in an 'Effect.run', instead.

abstract.text: Returns an effect that repeatedly emits the current time of the given scheduler on the given
interval.
Throttles an effect so that it only publishes one output per given interval.
Review unsupported effect APIs and their replacements.
Turns an effect into one that can be debounced.
Returns an effect that repeatedly emits the current time of the given scheduler on the given
interval.
Returns an effect that repeatedly emits the current time of the given scheduler on the given
interval.
A convenience type alias for referring to an effect that can never fail, like the kind of
returned by a reducer after processing an action.
Creates an effect that executes some work in the real world that doesn’t need to feed data
back into the store. If an error is thrown, the effect will complete and the error will be
ignored.
Throttles an effect so that it only publishes one output per given interval.
Creates an effect that can supply a single value asynchronously in the future.
Initializes an effect that immediately fails with the error passed in.
Initializes an effect that lazily executes some work in the real world and synchronously sends
that data back into the store.
Initializes an effect that wraps a publisher.
Returns an effect that will be executed after given
A protocol that describes how to evolve the current state of an application to the next state,
given an action, and describes what
s should be executed later by the store, if
any.
Initializes an effect that immediately emits the value passed in.
Turns an effect into one that can be debounced.
An effect that will cancel any currently in-flight effect with the given identifier.
Initializes an effect that lazily executes some work in the real world and synchronously sends
that data back into the store.
Initializes an effect from a callback that can send as many values as it wants, and can send
a completion.
The Composable Architecture (TCA, for short) is a library for building applications in a consistent
and understandable way, with composition, testing, and ergonomics in mind. It can be used in
SwiftUI, UIKit, and more, and on any Apple platform (iOS, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS).
A type that encapsulates a unit of work that can be run in the outside world, and can feed
actions back to the
A store represents the runtime that powers the application. It is the object that you will pass
around to views that need to interact with the application.
